10009.description: The 2018 International Human Rights Art Festival(ihraf.org), co-produced by The Wild Project (195 E. 3rd Street, Lower East Side), will take place the week of November 12- 18, 2018. This event will showcase 22 arts-advocacy events and performances oriented around human rights themes. For full information on the event, please visit our website or Facebook page ( https://www.facebook.com/HumanRightsArtFestival/) We are especially excited to extend this invitation to VolunteerMatch because of the unique chance to engage with artists, activists and politicians at a first-class NYC theater venue. Throughout the week of November 12-18, volunteers will have access to events and performances on the day(s) they volunteer (and receive a festival t-shirt!) Volunteers may sign up for as many 2-hour shifts as they like (though only one t-shirt total will be provided). We need volunteers between the following hours (we will have at least two volunteers scheduled for each slot): Monday-Friday: 11:30-1:30pm, 1:30-3:30pm, 3:30-5:30pm, 6:30-8:30pm, 8-10:30pm Saturday: 12:30-2:30pm, 2-4pm, 4-6pm, 6-8pm, 7:30-9:30pm, 9:30-11:30pm Sunday: 12:30-2:30pm, 2-4pm, 3:30-5:30pm, 5:30-7:30pm, 7-9pm, 8:30-10:30pm. Please go to https://www.signupgenius.com/go/70a0d4aaba72ea6fe3-international to sign up for your desired slot(s). We appreciate you considering this opportunity. Please feel free to share it with friends and family as well! We are also more than happy to field any questions you may have, so do not hesitate to reach out to ihrafvolunteers@gmail.com ! We look forward to seeing you and your community at the 2018 International Human Rights Art Festival!
10009.title: Volunteer for the 2018 International Human Rights Art Festival!

11510.description: As part of the office team, the clerical assistant will assist with duties such as filing, collating, faxing and various clerical duties.
11510.title: Clerical Assistant- External Affairs Department

07083.description: Take the kettle challenge! We need your help! The Red Kettle has been part of The Salvation Army's tradition since 1891. Today, kettles are part of The Salvation Army's efforts to raise funds so critical to our on-going operations. Unfortunately for some, the holiday season can mean unmanageable expenses, disappointed children, and empty stomachs. Bellringers can work alone or in pairs, encouraging pedestrian's to contribute with ringing and friendly demeanors. Our kettle stands are \"manned\" Monday thru Saturday from early November until December 24th. The Salvation Army will have already secured prior permission for you to stand at a designated location and all of the equipment will be provided. Only a four-hour time commitment is required and flexible hours make bell-ringing ideal for volunteers with tight schedules and families who want to share the kettle experience and help the needy. This opportunity is perfect for groups seeking a group project that will make a difference not just at this time of giving but throughout the year. Consider organizing a group from your corporation, school, service club, college, church etc that will commit to staffing a kettle for a day or more, simply rotate your members throughout the day in shifts. There will be many kettle locations throughout New Jersey, one of which I am sure will be convenient for you.
07083.title: Salvation Army bell ringer
07083.org: The Salvation Army - New Jersey Division

07086.description: The National MS Society is looking for volunteers to help with Bike MS: New York City’s Rest Stop location in Weehawken! Bike MS New York City will be held on Sunday, October 21 - Rest Stop volunteers are needed from 7:00am-9:00am in Weehawken, NJ. We welcome groups and individuals of all ages and abilities to join us as volunteers! Bike MS: New York City is a unique experience - the 30 mile route around Manhattan is completely traffic free. The 50 and 100 mile rides allow cyclists to ride through the Holland Tunnel traffic free. More than 300 volunteers are needed to make this event a success! If you are interested in volunteering, please review the position below and register online here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/20f0944acab22abfd0-201813 Rest Stop Support Team: Date: Sunday, October 21, 2018 Time: 6:30am-9:00am Location: Weehawken, NJ Description: Volunteers will be assigned to the Weehawken rest stop which is along the Bike MS: New York City route. Volunteers will distribute water, snacks and cheer on walkers! If you have any questions, please contact: NYC Volunteer Engagement Team at NYCSNY.Volunteers@nmss.org or 212-453-3258
07086.title: Rest Stop Volunteers Needed in Weehawken for Bike MS: NYC!
07086.org: National MS Society - New York City

07087.description: Use your skills to help the immigrant community and experience the joy of helping someone change their life. We are looking for committed volunteers to teach Spanish speaking students. Volunteers teach one, three-hour class a week for ten weeks. All classes are on Sundays. Previous teaching experience is not necessary, but commitment, ability and a desire to teach are key. Our teachers have included those with experience, those undergoing teacher training and those who have no experience at all. Some classes require Spanish speakers, but some do not. Comite En Union para Salvadorenos (CEUS) is a 501 (c)3 non-profit organization based in Union City, NJ that was founded by Central American refugees to help immigrants create a better life for themselves. The classes are now offered at Centro Comunitario CEUS, our community center 15 minutes from Manhattan. Our website is www.ceusnj.org. CEUS has organized ESL classes for 23 years.
07087.title: Teach English to immigrants - change your world and theirs!

10573.description: At The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS), we're passionate about our mission: to cure leukemia, lymphoma, Hodgkin's disease and myeloma, and improve the quality of life of patients and their families. LLS volunteers help carry out this mission in so many ways: supporting patients, family members, healthcare professionals, and our community, driving policy advocacy, participating in our campaigns, and helping LLS build much needed capacity. Product information The Office of Volunteer Engagement (OVE) works to ensure that the volunteer experience across LLS is a meaningful one and that volunteers help to build capacity across the organization. Purpose The purpose of this role is to help ensure a consistent volunteer experience by creating a series of standardized role descriptions for key volunteer positions using a standardized template. Having completed and consistent role descriptions will be critical to the integration of our new volunteer management platform, Digital Cheetah. Position Tasks Using the role description template, the Program Assistant will create standardized role descriptions for each major volunteer role In some instances a current description is in place and will just need to be updated for the new template In some instances a description will have to be created from publicity and other program materials using the template to ensure consistency After drafting all the descriptions, the Program Assistant will send them to staff for review and comment, finalize the descriptions based on staff feedback, and review them for consistency. Desired Skills Volunteer should possess the following skills/qualifications: An interest in the field of volunteer engagement and/or human resources Proficient at Microsoft word Good writing and proofreading skills Attention to detail Location National Office, 3 International Drive, Suite 200 Rye Brook, NY 10573. Some work may be done remotely with either in person or phone check-ins on a weekly basis. Time Commitment This project is expected to take between 40 and 80 hours to complete and must be completed by November 5. Shift Times Flexible schedule based on mutually agreed upon times. Work must be completed during business hours 9am - 5pm. Background check required No Training LLS will provide the volunteer with an orientation to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society including an overview of the volunteer program and introduction to the digital cheetah system. Benefits Free Parking Computer and work space provided solely for the purpose of this project Access to LLS resources (Patient Access, etc.) Opportunity to learn about an electronic volunteer management system Reference for college credit is possible. Need must be indicated at the time of volunteer interview for consideration.
10573.title: Volunteer Program Assistant

10573.description: Open Door Family Medical Center is partnering with Feeding Westchester (formerly the Food Bank of Westchester), to bring a free \"market on wheels\" to the Port Chester Community. Each month fresh, nutritious food will be provided to those-in-need. The food is set up as a farmer’s market so that people can walk through and select their own food, including fresh protein, dairy, produce and grains! Volunteers will help set up and distribute food products along with breaking down cardboard boxes. Location: Open Door Family Medical Center 5 Grace Church St, Port Chester, NY (Mobile Pantry in Parking Lot on Purdy St) Requirements: Able to lift 30 lbs. Spanish Language Skills beneficial High School Students Welcome! On-line Application Completed When: One Saturday a month August 25th, Sept. 15th, October 13th, November 10th, December 15th This is an express interest listing - a follow-up email will allow you to sign-up for available time-lots. For additional information, please contact Jane Levy, Manager of Volunteer Programs: jlevy@odfmc.org.
10573.title: FREE Nutritious Food - Help Distribute at Mobile Pantry
10573.org: Open Door Family Medical Centers Inc

08852.description: AKhil Autism Foundation Akhil Autism Foundation’s Fundraiser will be held on Saturday Oct 13 th 2018 at Cross Roads South Middle School, 195 Major Road , Monmouth Junction , NJ 08852 . We are expecting approximately 560 attendees for this benefit event, giving businesses like yours a unique opportunity to significantly expand your reach within the Tri-State area’s South Asian community. Today, the Center for Disease Control reports 1 in 59 children are diagnosed with autism spectrum disorders, significantly affecting families, schools and the community at large. As per new findings, its 1 in 37 now and research is crucial. Every 11 minutes another child is diagnosed with autism, costing families, on average, $60,000 per year. 1/3 of individuals with autism also have epilepsy. Not only must we find ways to improve the quality of life for children and adults with autism, but we must also find the causes and cure. The highest prevalence of autism currently is in New Jersey with 1 in 28 boys. Akhil Auti sm Foundation (AAF) is an NJ-based non-profit organization whose dedicated mission is to Educate, Treat, Support, and Research Autism worldwide, especially in under-served countries such as India. Since 2008, AAF has provided critical resources to 1000 children, over 500 hours of online education, and over$40,000in donations towards autism research, professional training, and parent education. To learn more about our group programs and activities, please visit our website (www.akhilautismfoundation.org) Krazy for Kishore is a great opportunity to support Autism cause and at the same time receive valuable exposure in the community. Funds raised will go towards Rutgers Brain Health Institute Research Pilot Project Award $40,000 and Startup cost for Integrative Treatment Center in NJ At present we need help with our upcoming fundraiser 1) https://www.tickethungama.co m/event/14797/krazy-for-kishor e-celebrating-kishoreda-in-nj. ........... ..For one ticket sell each volunteer will get 2 hrs 2)Marketing the krazy for kishore event in local communities............. . selling t-shirts, mouse pads, coaster. Each item sold 4 hrs of volunteering and AAF T-Shirt www.akhilautismfoundation.org/shop 3)Finding community partners: we will provide you package ... one community partner and you get 4 volunteering hours, AAF T-Shirt and shout out with your photo on our social media 4) Volunteers for Oct 13th 2018: information on the flyer please email programs@akhilautismfoundation.org
08852.title: Akhil Autism Foundation: Oct 13th 2018 Fundraiser

08854.description: Become a Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk Volunteer. Volunteers are the heart of the American Cancer Society and play an integral role in the fight against all cancers, including breast cancer. Your reasons for fighting back against breast cancer are as unique and special as the story that motivates you. Maybe you're volunteering in celebration of a loved one. Or maybe you are currently facing breast cancer yourself. When you join the American Cancer Society volunteer family, you’ll unite with people in your community who have been affected by breast cancer and you will use your passion to save more lives to make this breast cancer’s last century. Because silence won’t finish this fight action will. Our volunteers help with important event details such as registration, greeters, water stations, route marshall, set up/clean up and more. Want to take your dedication to end breast cancer to the next level? Join the fight to end breast cancer by contacting us about volunteer opportunities for our Making Strides of Edison, NJ walk. With your support, we can save more lives and finish the fight against breast cancer! Contact Patty Tapia at Patty.Tapia@cancer.org
08854.title: Making Strides Against Breast Cancer of Central NJ

11217.description: As a non profit for children with cancer we are asking for an Executive Director who has a lot of long term availability. We are hoping this person can do 10-15 hours per week and stay with the organization for minimum of 6 months. This role is really for someone who is between jobs, would like a transition position. Job Duties include, but are not limited to: Oversee and Direct General Fundraising Activities and Grant Applications. Act as a source of everyday operations. Be able to supervise and direct non profit interns and volunteers. Be able to attend events we have for the children in our Programs Department as well as PR/Marketing, and Fundraising. Guide the vision and Direction of the organization as established by the Founder. Financial/Personnel Management Oversee events, meetings, get togethers, etc. We are looking for someone who has an advanced degree such as a Master's Degree and previous work with a non profit. Leadership and interpersonal skills are required. Understanding of Google Docs, Microsoft Office, & Quickbooks Strong Financial Management Skills Excellent written and verbal skills Comfortable interacting with diverse families, organizations, and other communities. Able to manage multiple projects simultaneously.
11217.title: Executive Director Volunteer

06903.description: Assistant Treasurer with the following duties: Reviews weekly cash deposits Receive, organize and pay bills Input accounting activity into Quickbooks Closing accounting books on monthly, quarterly and annual basis Organizing and archiving financial records Hours are flexible: Thursday, Fridays & Saturdays between 10:00 and 12:00 If you fit the bill and would like to help us, please get in touch with me. Thanks for your interest! Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator - Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Assistant Treasurer / Bookeeper

06903.description: Come on out to the Stamford Museum & Nature Center's Heckscher Farm and join the volunteer team at Trick or Treat on the Farm. Volunteers will staff various activity stations around the farm and hand out goody bags. This opportunity is open to high school age and older volunteers. Middle school students may volunteer if they are accompanied by a parent.
06903.title: Trick or Treat on the Farm

06903.description: Media/News Writer Volunteer, If you enjoy writing, this is the volunteer job for you. We are looking for someone to create press releases about the Stamford History Center for distribution to various media outlets (onlinenews sites, radio, tv, magazines, etc.). You will interview people in the organization to gather information. Once your article is reviewed by our volunteer editors, it will be sent out. It is essential that our media volunteer stays up-to- date with our activities, so press releases go out in a timely fashion. The position can be expanded to include the creation of newsletters and flyers (working with our graphic designer). This is a job that can be done largely from your own laptop/desktop, and at your own convenience. REQUIREMENT: Please write a two or three paragraph \"Press Release\" on one of the following topics: 1] About our Tag Sale 2] The opening of the Hoyt-Barnum House or 3] A past Historical Center event You can get ideas by going to our web site: www.stamfordhistory.org Forward it to me and we will review and get back to you. Thanks again for your interest in joining the volunteer team! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org 203-329-1183 Skills needed: organized, experienced writer; a self-starter who can use Word and navigate the internet.
06903.title: Media/News Writer Volunteer

06903.description: Volunteer Help Wanted: Dynamic Education Program Docents! The Stamford Historical Society is looking for dedicated, enthusiastic and energetic individuals to staff its extremely successful education programs. If you enjoy working with children, want to share your enthusiasm for history, or are looking to broaden your own experience, becoming an Education Docent for the Stamford History Center is an excellent opportunity. Teaching experience is helpful, but not required. Docents will bring in classroom programs into elementary schools during the school year and host onsite programs at the Stamford History Center. All docents will be trained to lead our hands-on programs in a series of workshops. Programs take place on school days. The specific days and dates and hours will be confirmed with the school participants. PLEASE RESPOND via this site and we will get back to you. Thanks for your interest!
06903.title: School Outreach and Docent for Dynamic Education Program

06903.description: Welcome Visitors to the Museum; answer questions about Exhibits; respond to Phone Inquiries. Docent training provided at the start of each new exhibit. Time Commitment: Minimum 3 hours per week, during Museum hours. This is an especially good volunteer opportunity for students both during summer vacation time as well as fulfilling their school community service requirements.This position can be filled by students giving one Saturday afternoon a month to the Society. Seniors looking to meet new people and continue learning about their community have found this to be an interesting way to accomplish those goals. We are flexible in that volunteers can come in weekly or biweekly depending on their schedules.
06903.title: Docent / Tour Guide - Hoyt-Barnum House

06901.description: Stamford Academy serves about 135 high school students who have been unsuccessful in other schools. The number of students with Individual Education Plans (IEPs) is about twice the rate of Stamford Public Schools, yet Stamford is able to provide only one SPED teacher. You know how important one-on-one instruction is. Do you have a couple of hours to spare once a week during the school year to help tutor a student? Training provided. To meet our kids is to love them. They are wary and giving; have big dreams and struggle to stay on task; are talented and funny; and may have not had dinner the night before. If you'd like to know more, please contact me.
06901.title: Do you know what an IEP is? If so, read on...

10466.description: We are currently looking for writing/literary arts teachers for our literary programs. Words vs. Pictures: This is our visual and literary arts program and you may spend some time throughout the year working with an artist/teaching artist. You will have the opportunity to create your curriculum to teach our students different writing disciplines and engage them in projects related to self-expression/exploration, current events, and other subjects of interest. You will work with the students to create works suitable for a show/exhibit at the end of the year. Bookworms: This is our book club for young readers. The club meets once per month during the school year. Read thrilling books and do fun activities with elementary school aged children to build their love of reading. Beyond Words: This book club is for teens. The club meets once per month during the school year. Engage middle and high school students in reading books with themes relevant to today's events. We are looking for writers/teachers that can teach various literary arts disciplines - poetry, short essay, biography, etc. Please contact us whether you are interested in teaching for the whole school year, a semester, or a particular subject/discipline for a limited time. We are open to the right teacher or combination of teachers. At Artsmith, we are dedicated to providing arts education to young people in the Bronx who have little or no opportunity to experience the arts. We know that the arts provide our students with a great and safe place to learn creativity, experiment and take risks, develop discipline, and build confidence. Arts education should not be a question of access. You must believe in this mission to volunteer with us! Email resume to tricia.smith@artsmith.org to be considered.
10466.title: Writing/Literary Arts Teacher

10467.description: I'RAISE Offers an exciting and rewarding opportunity to individuals seeking to become a role model and make a positive impact on younger youth. This exciting opportunity includes one on one mentoring, group mentoring and/or mentoring. Mentors work with mentees on developing goals for their life that will help them make social, emotional and educational gains! Ideal candidates include college students. students who need internship experience/volunteer experience, retired professionals or individuals who simply want to make a difference! If you are seeking an opportunity to invest in a youth and make a positive difference.
10467.title: Big Brother/Big Sister Mentor

11553.description: This is our 3rd Annual Charity Ball Event, We are looking for volunteers to help us organize, set up, greeting and seating our guests. Also helping with serving food and drinking.
11553.title: M4Haiti 2018 Charity Ball

08863.description: Imagine if you couldn't read a prescription, job application, bedtime story or ballot. Become a volunteer literacy tutor and help adults improve their reading, writing, or English skills. Sign up for our next tutor training class! Saturdays October 6, 13, 20 & 27 from 10:30 am - 1:30 pm Location: Fords Library, 211 Ford Ave. Fords, NJ 08863 To register: Contact Melissa Bernstein at mbernstein@literacynj.org or 732-906-5456 Registration Fee: $45.00
08863.title: Become a Volunteer Tutor

10463.description: We need 6 volunteers to help set up and break down stations for our annual Halloween event. Specifically, volunteers would be needed from 3pm - 4pm and 6pm - 7pm for this activity whereas if you wanted to volunteer to make goodie bags (candy), you would be needed from 9:30 am until noon that day.
10463.title: Setup/ Breakdown Volunteer

10463.description: The Special Needs Program at the Kingsbridge Heights Community Center is designed to provide students with the same opportunities as all children in New York City, from fitness to creative spaces. We are looking for volunteers to help with our Respite After School Program on Mondays between the hours of 3:00 pm and 4:00 pm. The 3:00 pm - 4:00 pm would be for volunteers who are interested in running arts and crafts activities.
10463.title: Special Needs After-School Volunteer

10463.description: Position Statement: Evening classes, 6:00pm-9:30pm Monday - Thursday The ESOL (English Students of Other Languages) Program Assistant will be responsible for one-on-one support to students during classroom English lesson plans, administrative support to the instructor/s, and technical aspects of assisting students with progressing computer-based language programs. Duties and Responsibilities: Provide participants with one-on-one assistance Assist with technical and administrative tasks Provide administrative back-up and support to ESOL Instructor Engage and retain students by developing supportive relationships Other duties as assigned by Instructor Qualifications: HS Diploma; Some college preferred Comfort with computer applications and data entry Available evening hours Organized, efficient, and task oriented English/Spanish Bi-lingual helpful
10463.title: ESOL Program Volunteer

10463.description: VOLUNTEER POSITION DESCRIPTION The Secretary serves on the Board of Directors. The Secretary is also a member of the Executive Committee. KEY ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Attends monthly Board and/or Executive Committee virtual 60-75-minute meetings. Prepares minutes of key decisions using meeting recordings; distributes minutes in a timely fashion, within 7-14 days. Assists with Board meeting reminders and scheduling of GoToMeetings as needed. Sets up Board meeting schedule six months in advance. Assists with internal calendar postings, Outlook email as needed. Updates and distributes internal contacts list, Board Attendance tracking, and Organizational Chart. Participates in by-laws review and handles by-laws requests in coordination with the governance team. Contributes to Strategic Planning goals and action plans. Provides administrative support as needed. QUALIFICATIONS Proficiency in Word and Excel. Experience in Office 365 / Outlook a plus. Excellent writing and grammar skills. Strong project and time management skills with exceptional attention to detail. Volunteer Details Term: Two (2) Years Time Commitment: Minimum of 8-10 mostly virtual hours per month; which may include evenings. Please submit the following documents for consideration: Resume or CV. Bio of 100-300 words using III Bio Guidelines. Candidates may submit materials electronically via Word or PDF to volunteer@imageimpact.org. ABOUT IMAGE IMPACT INTERNATIONAL Image Impact International, Inc. (III) is a global Non-profit 501(c)(3) organization. Our mission is to mentor first-generation students to remain in college. FOR MORE INFORMATION Contact VP-Human Resources Marisol Rosero-Allen at volunteer@imageimpact.org.
10463.title: Board Secretary - New York Metro Area

10460.description: Artsmith is a young nonprofit providing arts programming to children in the Bronx. We are currently looking for artists and/or teaching artists for various programs and events our organization runs. Words vs. Pictures: Words vs. Pictures is our visual and literary arts program serving elementary and middle school students. The program is designed to teach students ways to express themselves and explore important topics using various writing and art methods. We are looking for artists/teaching artists that can teach one or more visual arts disciplines - drawing/sketching, painting, photography, sculpture, etc. The program meets once per week on Saturday afternoons. Contact us whether you'd like to teach a single class or make a longer commitment. Paint and Sip: Our paint and sips are fundraisers that are held at local Bronx breweries or restaurants. If you are a painter interested in leading these events please contact us. We will provide the necessary materials for the participants. At Artsmith, we are dedicated to providing arts education to young people in the Bronx who have little or no opportunity to experience the arts. We know that the arts provide our students with a great and safe place to learn creativity, experiment and take risks, develop discipline, and build confidence. Arts education should not be a question of access. You must believe in this mission to volunteer with us! Email resume and 2-3 art samples to tricia.smith@artsmith.org.
10460.title: Artist/Teaching Artist

10460.description: There is a tremendous need, especially for high-risk youth in low-income neighborhoods in The Bronx municipality, for programs that provide activities and support for children during the after school hours and throughout the summer and ACN has stepped up to take the responsibility in addressing this problem through our new initiative (ACN YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING) Project. In 1998, the Children’s Defense Fund reported that violent crime by young people ages 10-17 peaks between 3 and 7 PM; children and teens in poor neighborhoods are struggling for direction and positive opportunities are needed to keep them safe and on-track; a great majority of all American fourth graders cannot read or do math at grade level, including more than five of six black children. In addition, a study published in Pediatrics magazine found that eighth graders who were left alone after school reported greater use of cigarettes, marijuana, and alcohol than those in adult-supervised settings. Current research indicates that supervised after-school and summer programs not only keep children safe and out of trouble, they also significantly improve their academic achievement. PROJECT DESCRIPTION Teaching high-risk, inner-city Youth the skills to become successful in life is at the core of the ACN SUMMER YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING program. The Four(4) major components of the program are: *Homework Assistance through tutoring, mentoring and Use of Computer labs. *Nutrition Education to promote healthy lifestyles and Combat Obesity. *Life Skills which are integrated throughout all phases of the program. *Soccer Instructions where participants engage in fun physical fitness, enjoy the camaraderie of playing in a soccer team format with friends and peers, and learn to become responsible adolescents and adults. The summer After-School Program- will serve approximately 600 children which includes academic tutoring five(5) hours per week and Soccer Instruction, Health and life skills education ten(10) hours per week. Participants will receive Soccer Instruction in professional settings and practice skills in team format play. They will learn about the rules of the game, etiquette, sportsmanship, positive attitudes, fair play, self-esteem, taking responsibility for choices and management of emotions. These life skills are integrated throughout the Soccer program, and instructors routinely demonstrate how they apply to situations in all aspects of life. Nutrition and Healthy lifestyles are stressed both in the Classroom setting and on the Soccer Field. Healthy Snacks will be provided. The ACN YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING program is Fortunate to have a corpse of Volunteers willing to dedicate to the program and are available to work with the children on improving their academic skills. Seeking Volunteers from some of the community based Universities/colleges who will take an active role in the homework area, working individually with the students using current homework assignments. In the computer lab, Volunteer tutors will help the students improve their keyboarding skills and show them how to use the computer for research. They will read aloud with the students and give quizzes on tapes and videos to improve comprehension. When the college/university students volunteers are not on campus, volunteers from local Churches will assume the role of tutors. Incentives will be awarded to the participants based on attendance, good behavior and general attitude.
10460.title: ACN YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT

11793.description: In 2016 we launched the Comeback Trail series. For the first time, the stroke community had an opportunity to come together to raise stroke awareness and celebrate survivorship by walking or running together on the Comeback Trail. In 2018, we expanded our Comeback Trail series to 14 cities across the U.S. and are looking for volunteers to help support us at each event. You can expect this to be a fun, fast-paced event with opportunities to help in a few different areas. Although each volunteer will be assigned to one main responsibility, this will be an all hands on deck type of event. Potential volunteer responsibilities include: setting up the 5K course with cones, mile markers, and start/finish lines; helping race participants register and receive their t-shirt and bib; directing traffic through designated parking areas; cheering on participants during the race; passing out water to race participants; passing out educational information on stroke at our awareness table.
11793.title: Join Us on the Comeback Trail - Long Island

11793.description: Put your passion to work as a Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Volunteer. Breast cancer is a personal cause to many people. Perhaps you have personally faced the disease or you have had friends or family members who have. Volunteers are the heart of the American Cancer Society and events like Making Strides walks simply could not happen without you. Your support will bring you community together with determination, hope, empathy, caring, and passion, so no one has to walk alone. The American Cancer Society Making Strides Against Breast Cancer walks raise awareness and funds to save lives from breast cancer. Each event is a noncompetitive 5 mile walk that brings people together to make a difference for everyone who has been touched by breast cancer. The events raise money to fund innovative research, provide free information and support, and to help people reduce their breast cancer risk or find it early when it's most treatable. From the opening ceremony to the post-walk entertainment, a Making Strides event is a celebration of survivors and opportunity to remember loved-ones lost. It's a day that shouldn't be missed and won't be forgotten. For more information please visit www.makingstrideswalk.org/longisland or email Christine.haskell@cancer.org On your email please have your name ( first and last ), Your email address, phone number, alone with your mailing address. Opportunity Areas: Include but not limited to: *Set-up (Saturday October 14th) *Breakdown (Sunday October 15) *Sponsor Welcom/Assistance *General Event Volunteer *Check-In *Tent Volunteer *Refreshment Distribution *Route Cheerleader *Water Station(s) *Merchandise Sales *Stage Entertainment *Face Painting *Temporary Tattoo *Survivor Masseuse *Hair Decorator
11793.title: Event Volunteer - Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk

07470.description: Every child has a chance - it's you. Learn about the Passaic County Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) volunteer program and how you can make a difference in the lives of Passaic County children in foster care. CASA volunteers are trained, dedicated adults who look out for a child's best interests while helping him or her move toward a safe and permanent home. CASAs have been best described as the \"eyes and ears\" of the Family Court. From helping siblings find permanent homes together to helping a child access needed services to uncovering information that helps reunite a loving family, CASA volunteers make an incredible difference to the lives of abused and neglected children. Currently, there are more than 250 children who are waiting for an advocate just like you. Stop by and learn more!
07470.title: Become a volunteer advocate for children in foster care!
07470.org: CASA for Children of Passaic County

11791.description: Assistant Coaches needed for either or both Wednesdays and/or Fridays. Girls on the Run is looking for some energetic people to help lead this curriculum based program. Starts in mid September and ends with a 5K on December 2nd. You do not need to run to coach with this program. Please see our website for more info www.gotrlongisland.org
11791.title: Assistant Coaches - Village Elementary School Syosset
11791.org: GIRLS ON THE RUN LONG ISLAND INC

08901.description: JDRF One Walk is our flagship fundraising event and the largest type 1 diabetes event in the world. Join us as a volunteer to help JDRF create a fantastic, fun festival for our One Walk participants! The Role: Photographer: Arrive early to set up camera equipment. You will be taking staged team photos as well as candid photos of the walk throughout the day.
08901.title: Volunteer Photographer - JDRF One Walk, Rutgers

08901.description: Volunteer roles: Check-in Crew: Assist with early morning set up, volunteer check-in, T-shirt distribution or participant check-in. Cheer Crew: High energy volunteers needed to cheer on our participants as they start the walk and cross the finish line. Snack & Pack Crew: Assist with early morning set up, food and beverage set up and event breakdown. Volunteer shifts are available. Groups - such as Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, school clubs and organizations, - are welcome to volunteer together.
08901.title: Volunteer at JDRF One Walk and help find a cure for T1D! Rutgers University

08901.description: Help combat community hunger at the 5 Loaves Pantry. Volunteers help unload and sort food, organize pantry items, and assist clients with shopping.
08901.title: Marketplace in New Brunswick

07106.description: Be the role model she'll always remember. As a volunteer, you’ll introduce girls to new experiences that show them they’re capable of more than they ever imagined. You’ll be their cheerleader, guide, and mentor, helping them develop skills and confidence that will last a lifetime. Imagine the smiles, the excitement, the memories made-those are the moments you’ll share at Girl Scouts. Sound like something you’re interested in? We know you have what it takes to be an amazing volunteer and we’re here to get you started on our journey! Be the troop leader that supports her throughout the year-the one that watches her smile get bigger as she grows more confident. Mentor a Girl Scout Cookie Professional during cookie season so she can earn enough to reach the goals she and her troop set. Or work with other adults to provide the kind of behind-the-scenes support that makes it possible for her to make amazing new memories at Girl Scouts. Troop Leader/Co-Leader Work with a group of girls and mentor them as they make new friends and develop connections that will last a lifetime.
07106.title: Girl Scout Heart of New Jersey, Leaders, Mentors and Advisors
07106.org: Girl Scouts Heart of New Jersey
